info.title: DSH Tenant Resource Management REST API

tags.description: Manage pre-packaged, easily configured apps that you can select from the App Catalog.
tags.name: app catalog

tags.description: Configure apps you start from the App Catalog.
tags.name: app catalog app configuration

tags.description: Query what's in the App Catalog.
tags.name: app catalog manifest

tags.description: Manage the sharing of object stores with other tenants and with the outside world.
tags.name: bucket access

tags.description: Manage access to the object stores of other tenants.
tags.name: third party bucket

tags.description: Managed a scalable, PostgreSQL compatible, relational database.
tags.name: database

tags.description: Manage opt-in for data catalog assets.
tags.name: data catalog

tags.description: Manage the limits of other tenants.
tags.name: managed tenant limits

tags.description: Request and renew Tenant API tokens.
tags.name: robot

200.description: Returns a json object where the key is the name of an application, and the value is it's respective configuration.

get.summary: Returns the configuration of every application created by a given tenant.

delete.summary: deletes an application by a specified application id

200.description: Returns the service definition of a given application identifier and tenant

get.summary: Returns the configuration of a certain application, specified by the tenant name and application name.

requestBody.description: a JSON containing the configuration of the application you want to deploy

put.summary: creates an application allocation, or update it's configuration

200.description: returns a JSON object containing the configurations of all application allocations as they are actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration. If an application is stuck while deploying, it will not show up here.

get.summary: returns a list containing the configuration of every deployed application of a given tenant

200.description: returns a JSON object containing the configuration of an application allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration. If an application is stuck while deploying, it will not show up here.

get.summary: returns the configuration of a deployed application allocation for a given app id and tenant

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: returns a status description of an application allocation

200.description: configuration of all App Catalog App allocations of a tenant. This may differ from the wanted configuration. This shows the complete configuration of the App Catalog App. To only view the configuration parameters of this allocation, see the `appcatalogappconfiguration` section.

get.summary: returns a list containing all App Catalog App allocations and their respective configurations of a given tenant

200.description: configuration of all App Catalog App allocations as they are actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration. This shows the complete configuration of the App Catalog App. To only view the configuration parameters of this allocation, see the `appcatalogappconfiguration` section.

get.summary: returns a list containing all App Catalog App allocations and their respective configurations of a given tenant, as they are actually deployed

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of an appcatalogapp allocation

get.summary: returns the configuration of an App Catalog App allocation by a specified tenant name and App Catalog App Id. To only view the configuration parameters of this allocation, see the `appcatalogappconfiguration` section.

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of an App Catalog App allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration. If an application is stuck while deploying, it will not show up here.

get.summary: returns the configuration of an App Catalog App allocation as it is actually deployed. To only view the configuration parameters of this allocation, see the `appcatalogappconfiguration` section.

202.description: the delete request has been accepted

200.description: A JSON Object containing the wanted configuration of an App Catalog App

get.summary: Returns the wanted configuration of an App Catalog App by its tenant name and AppCatalogApp Id. If an App Catalog App is stuck while deploying and not on actual, it will show up here.

requestBody.description: JSON object containing required parameters for AppCatalogApp manifest. This is comparable to the configuration object on a regular Application service.

put.summary: creates a new App Catalog App, or update its configuration

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: gets status description of an App Catalog App

200.description: lists AppCatalog manifests

get.summary: returns a list of AppCatalog manifests for a given tenant

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: lists all bucketwatches of a tenant

200.description: the overall status of a specific bucketwatch allocation

get.summary: shows overall status of a bucketwatch allocation

200.description: configuration

get.summary: gets configuration of a bucketwatch allocation

put.summary: creates bucketwatch configuration.

200.description: configuration of a bucketwatch allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration

get.summary: gets actual configuration of a bucketwatch allocation

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: gets status description of a bucketwatch allocation

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: lists all bucket names of a tenant

200.description: the overall status of a specific bucket allocation along with the bucket's configured and actual state

get.summary: shows overall status of a bucket allocation

200.description: configuration

get.summary: gets configuration of a bucket allocation

requestBody.description: the JSON representation of the resource

put.summary: creates bucket configuration.It is impossible to update an existing bucket. This requires a delete of the existing bucket and creation of a new one with the wanted configuration.

200.description: configuration of a bucket allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration

get.summary: gets actual configuration of a bucket allocation

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: gets status description of a bucket allocation

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: lists all bucketaccesses of a tenant

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: shows bucketaccesses about a specific bucket

200.description: the overall status of a specific bucketaccess allocation along with the its configured and actual state

get.summary: shows overall status of a third party bucket

200.description: configuration

get.summary: gets configuration of a bucketaccess allocation

requestBody.description: the wanted config of the (new) bucketaccess allocation

put.summary: creates bucketaccess configuration.

200.description: configuration of a bucketaccess allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration

get.summary: gets actual configuration of a bucketaccess allocation

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: gets status description of a bucketaccess allocation

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: returns a list of all certificate names that are allocated to a tenant

200.description: a JSON object containing the overall status of a specific certificate allocation along with the certificate's configuration and  its actual state

get.summary: returns the status of a specific certificate allocation by id

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of a certain certificate

get.summary: returns the configuration of a certificate allocation

requestBody.description: the JSON object containing the configuration of a certificate. certChainSecret and keySecret must be known to the platform.

put.summary: create a new certificate. It is impossible to update an existing certificate. This requires a delete of the existing certificate and creation of a new one with the wanted configuration.

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of a certificate allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration

get.summary: returns the actual configuration of a certificate allocation. This may not represent the wanted configuration.

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: returns a brief status description of a certificate allocation

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: (beta release) lists ids of all databases of a tenant

200.description: the overall status of a specific database allocation along with the database's configured and actual state

get.summary: (beta release) gets overall status of a database allocation

200.description: returns the configuration for this database allocation

get.summary: (beta release) gets configuration for a database allocation

requestBody.description: the JSON representation of the resource

put.summary: (beta release) creates a database configuration. It is impossible to update an existing database.

200.description: configuration of a database allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration

get.summary: (beta release) gets actual state for a database allocation

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: (beta release) gets status description of a database allocation

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: lists all data catalog assets of a tenant for the given kind

200.description: the overall status of a specific data catalog asset allocation along with the asset's configured and actual state

get.summary: shows overall status of a datacatalog asset allocation

200.description: configuration

get.summary: gets configuration of a data catalog asset allocation

requestBody.description: the JSON representation of the resource

put.summary: creates dataCatalogAsset configuration.

200.description: a JSON object containing a Flink Cluster's overall status, actual state and its configuration

get.summary: returns the overall status of a Flink Cluster

delete.summary: deletes a Flink Cluster. Since only one cluster can be created per tenant, only the tenants' name needs to be specified.

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of a Flink Cluster

get.summary: returns the configuration of a Flink Cluster

requestBody.description: a JSON object containing the desired configuration of the Flink Cluster. Zone must be known to the platform.

put.summary: create a new Flink Cluster. It is impossible to update an existing Flink Cluster. This requires a delete of the existing Flink Cluster and creation of a new one with the wanted configuration.

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of a Flink Cluster as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration

get.summary: returns the actual configuration of a Flink Cluster.

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: returns a brief status description of a Flink Cluster

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: returns a list of all kafka proxies of a tenant

200.description: Returns the service definition of a given kafka proxy

get.summary: Returns the configuration of a certain kafka Proxy, specified by the tenant name and kafka Proxy name.

200.description: the secret value is updated

put.summary: update the value of the kafka proxy

200.description: configuration of a kafka proxy allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration

get.summary: Returns the actual deployment state of a kafka proxy, specified by the tenant name and kafka proxy name.

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: returns a status description of a kafkaproxy allocation

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: list tenant Kafka ACL groups

200.description: Returns the Kafka ACL group definition

get.summary: return the configuration of the Kafka ACl group

put.summary: creates a new or updates an existing Kafka ACL group

200.description: triggers the generation of a new Client Secret for the tenant’s robot account.  __This automatically invalidates the existing client secret __, and returns a new client secret in the response body!

post.summary: generate new client secret for a tenant

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: returns a list of all secret names of a tenant

requestBody.description: a JSON object containing the name and the secret value

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of this secret allocation

get.summary: returns the configuration of a secret allocation

200.description: The response body will be empty, but a 200 response indicates that the secret is created.

get.summary: returns the actual state of a secret. The response body will always be empty because we cannot share the secret value, but the response code will tell you more about its state.

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: returns a brief status description of a secret allocation

200.description: the secret value as a string

get.summary: returns the value of a secret

requestBody.description: the secret value as a string

200.description: the secret value is updated

put.summary: update the value of a secret

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: return a list containing the ids of all applications with derived tasks

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: return a list containing the ids of an application's derived tasks

200.description: a JSON object containing the overall status of a specific task allocation along with the task's configured and actual state

get.summary: returns overall status of a task

200.description: a JSON object containing the actual state of a specific task. This may differ from the task's configured state

get.summary: returns the actual state of a specific task

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: returns a brief status description of a task

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: lists only bucket names of a tenant that originated from a third party bucket

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: list summaries of third party buckets, registered using credentials shared to you by a third party

201.description: the third party bucket has been registered, and should soon be listable together with the resulting bucket.

post.summary: register a new bucket concession for which credentials were shared to you by a third party

parameters.description: your name of choice for the third party bucket
parameters.name: id

200.description: the overall status of a specific third party bucket along with the concession's configured and actual state

get.summary: shows overall status of a third party bucket

parameters.description: your name of choice for the third party bucket
parameters.name: id

parameters.description: your name of choice for the third party bucket
parameters.name: id

delete.summary: unregisters a third party bucket. This will also remove the virtual bucket.

parameters.description: your name of choice for the third party bucket
parameters.name: id

200.description: configuration

get.summary: gets configuration of a third party bucket (received bucket access) allocation

parameters.name: id

200.description: configuration

get.summary: gets actual configuration of a third party bucket (received bucket access) allocation

parameters.description: your name of choice for the third party bucket
parameters.name: id

parameters.description: your name of choice for the third party bucket
parameters.name: id

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: gets status description of third party bucket (received bucket access) allocation

parameters.description: your name of choice for the third party bucket
parameters.name: id

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: returns a list of topics of a tenant

200.description: a JSON object containing the overall status of a specific topic allocation along with the topic's configured and actual state

get.summary: returns the overall status of a topic allocation

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of a topic allocation

get.summary: returns the configuration of a topic allocation

requestBody.description: the JSON object containing the configuration of the desired topic

put.summary: create a new topic. It is impossible to update an existing topic. This requires a delete of the existing topic and creation of a new one with the wanted configuration.

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of a topic allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration

get.summary: returns actual configuration of a topic allocation

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: returns a brief status description of a topic allocation

200.description: returns a list of ids representing child resources of the requested resource

get.summary: returns a list containing the ids of all volumes of a given tenant

200.description: a JSON object containing the overall status of a specific volume allocation along with the volume's configured and actual state

get.summary: returns the overall status of a volume allocation

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration for a volume allocation

get.summary: returns the configuration for a volume allocation

requestBody.description: the JSON object containing the desired configuration of a volume allocation

put.summary: create a new volume configuration. It is impossible to update an existing volume. This requires a delete of the existing volume and creation of a new one with the wanted configuration.

200.description: a JSOn object containing the configuration of a volume allocation as it is actually deployed. This may differ from the wanted configuration

get.summary: returns the actual state for a volume allocation

example.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

200.description: status of the allocation

get.summary: returns a brief status description of a volume allocation

parameters.description: Name of the tenant that is acting as manager for this request

get.summary: returns a list of tenants managed by the `manager` tenant

parameters.name: manager

delete.summary: deletes a managed tenant for the managing tenant

parameters.description: Name of the tenant that is acting as manager for this request
parameters.name: manager

200.description: a JSON object containing the configuration of a managed tenant as it is configured on the current system.  This may differ from the wanted configuration.

get.summary: returns the configuration of tenant as managed by the manager

parameters.name: manager

requestBody.description: the JSON object containing the configuration of the managed tenant

env.MY_VARIABLE: { concat('I am running on ', variables('DSH_ENVIRONMENT'), ' blank     ') }

value.derivedFrom: optional URN of optional parent allocation

publicManagedStreamWithDefaultKafkaParti.description: a public managed stream with a default kafka partitioner

publicManagedStreamWithTopicLevelPartiti.description: a public managed stream with a topic level partitioner

managedTenantLimitListAll.description: an example of all managed tenant limits as a list

managedTenantLimitListSome.description: an example of some managed tenant limits as a list

managedTenantLimitCpu.description: an example of the managed tenant limit for vCPU quota

managedTenantLimitMem.description: an example of the managed tenant limit for memory (MiB)

managedTenantLimitCertificateCount.description: an example of the managed tenant limit for certificates

managedTenantLimitSecretCount.description: an example of the managed tenant limit for secrets

managedTenantLimitTopicCount.description: an example of the managed tenant limit for topics

managedTenantLimitPartitionCount.description: an example of the managed tenant limit for partitions

managedTenantLimitConsumerRate.description: an example of the managed tenant limit for Kafka consumer rate (bytes/s)

managedTenantLimitProducerRate.description: an example of the managed tenant limit for Kafka producer rate (bytes/s)

managedTenantLimitRequestRate.description: an example of the managed tenant limit for Kafka request rate (%)

kafkaProxy.description: an example of a Kafka proxy configuration

bucketaccessactual.description: a example BucketAccess as actually deployed

dataCatalogAssetBucket.description: an example data catalog asset for a bucket

dataCatalogAssetWritableStream.description: an example data catalog asset for a public writablestream

Manager.description: Name of the tenant that is acting as manager for this request
Manager.name: manager

ManagedStreamId.description: id of the managed stream, including the type prefix
ManagedStreamId.name: streamId

ActualCertificate.description: information on a certificate which is provisioned on the platform

derivedFrom.description: pointer to the parent allocation or limit that caused this allocation to be implicitly created

provisioned.description: indicates whether configuration and actual state match

cpus.description: How many CPUs this application needs (0.5 = 50% of 1 cpu)

mem.description: Amount of memory your application needs in MB

exposedPorts.description: Exposes ports of your application outside the platform

instances.description: Number of instances that need to be spun up for this app

needsToken.description: If true, the platform will provision a secret token in the `DSH_SECRET_TOKEN` environment variable. This token can be exchanged for a client certificate that can be used for authentication to, amongst others, the Kafka brokers.

singleInstance.description: If true, the platform will ensure that there is always at most one instance of this application running at the same time. This impacts restart and upgrade behavior: A single-instance application will be terminated before a replacement is started, whereas an application that is not single-instance will remain running until its replacement has started and reports healthy. **Note** Applications that define volumes are always implicitly treated as single-instance, even if this flag is not set.

user.description: The userid:groupid combination used to start the application container.

spreadGroup.description: The spread group - if any - to be used to ensure instances of one or more applications are not scheduled onto the same node.

topics.description: names of scratch topics to which the application needs access.

readableStreams.description: names of streams to which the application needs read access.

writableStreams.description: names of streams to which the application needs write access.

volumes.description: The volumes to be mounted in the container. The dictionary key is the mount point.

ApplicationSecret.description: a secret to be injected as an environment variable in the application

injections.description: a list of environment variable names. The secret's value may be injected multiple times as different environment variables, so multiple environment variable names for the same secret can be provided

configuration.description: configuration parameters to be used in AppCatalog manifest

Certificate.description: information on a certificate which is wanted on the platform but may not yet be provisioned

zone.description: Network zone this cluster needs to run in. /components/schemas/Zone contains a list of available network zones in this platform.

cpus.description: CPU quota for the Flink job manager (minimum 0.3 = 30% of 1 CPU)

mem.description: Memory (MB) for this Flink job manager (minimum 1024 = 1 GB)

cpus.description: CPU quota for each Flink task manager (minimum 0.3 = 30% of 1 CPU)

mem.description: Memory (MB) for each Flink task manager (minimum 1024 = 1 GB)

port.description: The TCP port for the health check

path.description: The HTTP path for the health check

protocol.description: The protocol for for the health check (http or https)

KafkaAclGroup.description: information about a Kafka ACL group

name.description: Name of the new Kafka Proxy

cpus.description: CPU quota for each Kafka Proxy (minimum 0.3 = 30% of 1 CPU)

mem.description: Memory (MB) for each Kafka Proxy (minimum 1024 = 1 GB)

secretNameCaChain.description: Secret name containing the Ca Cert

certificate.description: Secret name with the server certificate

schemaStore.description: Set to True no enable Schema Store

schemaStoreCpus.description: CPU quota for Schema Store (minimum 0.3 = 30% of 1 CPU)

enableKafkaAclGroups.description: Set to True to enable the ACL groups (Advanced feature: without the correct acl groups in place this will result in a non-functioning proxy instance)

KafkaProxyValidation.description: client certificate validations, only non empty values taken in account, no values means no validation

subjectType.description: EXACT for exact match, PATTERN for pattern match

ManagedStream.description: An internal stream.  A stream that can be shared between different tenants, but is not accessible over the MQTT protocol adapter.

PublicManagedStream.description: A public stream.  A stream that can be shared between different tenants, and is accessible over the MQTT protocol adapter.

PublicManagedStreamContract.description: The stream contract for a public stream.

canBeRetained.description: Whether MQTT records can have the "retained" flag.

partitioner.description: The partitioner used to partition messages across different kafka partitions.

ManagedStreamId.description:
The id of a managed stream consists of a managing prefix set specifically as a limit  for each managing tenant, and name of the stream. The managing prefix and the name are separated by `---` (three hyphens).
For an stream called `maerts` for a tenant with an assigned managing prefix `tnanet` the full name would be `tnanet---maerts`. The public or internal type of the particular stream is set by using the corresponding `/public/` or `/internal/` methods in the managed streams API.

name.description: Name of the tenant.  Must be identical to the tenant name used in the path.

manager.description:
Name of the tenant that is acting as manager for this tenant.  
Must be identical to the `manager` parameter in the path.

services.description:
List of services that are enabled for this tenant.  At this point, `monitoring` is a requirement (it's 
`enabled` value must be `true`).  The default values for `tracing` and `vpn` are both `false`.  The `vpn`
service is only available on some platforms.  Requesting it on a platform that doesn't support it will 
cause the request to be rejected.

Metrics.description: metrics endpoint which will be scraped by the platform.

port.description: The TCP port for the metrics endpoint

path.description: The HTTP path for the metrics endpoint

remove.description: true if the notification has to do with removal of the allocation, false if it relates to creation/update of the resource

mode.description:
Routing mode. The allowed values are:
  * `http` (default if this property is omitted). HTTP routing and TLS termination are done by the platform. In this case, the `tls` and (optionally) `paths` settings should be configured as well.
  * `tcp/<endpoint>`. The platform only does plain TCP routing, with TLS pass-through. When set, the `tls` and `paths` settings are ignored. The application is responsible for TLS termination and certificate management. There are various possible values for `<endpoint>` that may appear when listing allocation configurations, but the only value that is allowed to be set in regular application allocations is `tcp/https`.
    * `tcp/https`. Any traffic arriving on `<vhost>:443` will be forwarded (TLS included) to the service.
    * `tcp/kafka-proxy` is used by Kafka Proxies. This endpoint is auto-configured by the platform when allocating a Kafka Proxy application and should *not* be used when allocating regular applications.
    * `tcp/vpn-tcp` is used by a VPN application. This endpoint is auto-configured by the platform when allocating a VPN application and should *not* be used when allocating regular applications.

paths.description: The paths which are allowed on the associated vhost

tls.description: The default is 'auto', indicating that the port will only accept secured connections. Put this to 'none' if you do not want the service to have a secure endpoint.

vhost.description: The host name that needs to be assigned to this port (for multiple names, separate them with commas)

whitelist.description: Put ip addresses or ip ranges that can call this service here (for multiple addresses, separate them with spaces)

serviceGroup.description: To load balance traffic between different services, use this optional field to put those services in the same service group. Choose any name consisting of all lowercase letters.

prefix.description: The path prefix (starting with `/`, ending without `/`) that will be matched for routing to this service.

healthy.description: false or true depending on health checks (empty if no health checks)

host.description: The IP address of the host the task is running on (not the IP address of the task itself)

logs.description: Optional link to the latest log dump for this task

lastUpdate.description: Timestamp of the last time the task was updated

state.description: The state the task is in

kafkaProperties.description:
Additional Kafka properties to be set on the topic. The properties are key-value pairs.
The key is the property name and the value is the property value.  The following properties are allowed:
  - `cleanup.policy`: `delete|compact`
  - `compression.type`: `uncompressed|zstd|lz4|snappy|gzip|producer`
  - `delete.retention.ms`: min 0
  - `max.message.bytes`: min `1024`, max `1048576` (1024x1024)
  - `message.timestamp.type`: `CreateTime|LogAppendTime`
  - `retention.bytes` min 0
  - `retention.ms` min `3600000` (1 hour), max: `3,1536E+10` (365 days)
  - `segment.bytes`: min `52428800` (1024x1024x50)

KafkaProperties.description:
Additional Kafka properties to be set on the topic. The properties are key-value pairs.
The key is the property name and the value is the property value.  The following properties are allowed:
  - `cleanup.policy`: `delete|compact`
  - `compression.type`: `uncompressed|zstd|lz4|snappy|gzip|producer`
  - `delete.retention.ms`: min 0
  - `max.message.bytes`: min `1024`, max `1048576` (1024x1024)
  - `message.timestamp.type`: `CreateTime|LogAppendTime`
  - `retention.bytes` min 0
  - `retention.ms` min `3600000` (1 hour), max: `3,1536E+10` (365 days)
  - `segment.bytes`: min `52428800` (1024x1024x50)

name.description: the name you give to the third party bucket you are registering

shareidentifier.description: provided to you by the third party

credentialidentifierplaintext.description: plaintext credential identifier provided to you by the third party

credentialsecretplaintext.description: plaintext secret value provided to you by the third party

name.description: your name for this bucket owned by a third party
your name for this bucket owned by a third party
the full name of the volume that needs to be mounted in the container.

value.description: The number of CPUs to provision for the managed tenant (factions of a vCPU core, 1.0 equals 1 vCPU)
The amount of memory available for the managed tenant (MiB)
The number of certificates available for the managed tenant
The number of secrets available for the managed tenant
The number of topics available for the managed tenant
The number of partitions available for the managed tenant
The number of Kafka ACL groups available for the managed tenant
